Introduction
About &app;
Sound Juicer Manual sound-juicer
&app; is a simple and clean CD ripper tool. It allows you to extract the audio from audio compact discs and convert them into a variety of audio formats your computer can understand and play.
It has several useful features, for instance it can look up the titles and artists of the tracks on your CD from the internet, using the freely available MusicBrainz service.
Notice
&app; is currently in development, so this manual may not reflect the program as you see it. If it doesn't, please file a bug in Gnome bugzilla against sound-juicer, or email &mike-addr;
Using &app;
When you start &app;, it will examine the CD in the currently selected drive, and try and locate information about its contents. It can match against things like the serial number, but also the length and positions of the tracks - this means that sometimes you may get a false hit, and the details will be filled out incorrectly. Don't worry though, they are easy to change.
This is what &app; typically looks like when first started:
&app; on startup
&app; at startup
At the top of the window there are a couple of entry boxes for the disc artist and title. You should fill this out appropriately for the disc currently in the drive. For instance, if the disc is an album, put the artist and the name of the album in these entry boxes. For a single, the name of the artist and the track will do (as you can see in the above screenshot). If the disc is by multiple artists, you can just put "Various" or leave it blank.
That information is placed in the resultant files so they can be easily catalogued and searched by music playing software later, so it's a good idea to try and fill it out accurately - it will make finding and sorting them much easier.
Each track also has a title and artist field, which should be set appropriately. Again, this information will be encoded into the output files. You don't have to extract every track on the CD, if you'd like to exclude some, uncheck the box in the "Extract?" column. You can toggle the status of all the tracks at once by using the Edit menu.
When you edit the disc artist field (at the top), all the track artist fields are updated to reflect that. This saves you a lot of typing - as most discs are by a single artist, it means you only have to enter it once for the artist field to be updated everywhere.
The Duration field shows you the total length of the CD in the current drive.
The Re-read button is useful for when you change CDs but don't want to restart the program - pressing it will cause &app; to update its list of tracks.
When things are set up to your liking, press the Extract button, and &app; will begin reading the audio from the CD and saving it to disk. By default, this is the "~/Music" directory in your home directory, but you can change it in the Preferences window.
Extracting a CD can take a long time, depending on the speed of your computer. By default &app; compresses the audio at the same time as extracting it from the CD so it takes less space on disk, however this is a time consuming process. You don't have to sit and watch it though, just minimize it, or move it to a different virtual desktop.
Preferences
The preferences window allows you to control:
Which CD drive &app; uses if you have more than one
Where the extracted audio is placed on disk
Which file format/codec is used for the extracted audio
Preferences window
Preferences window
If you have multiple CD drives in your system, there is a drop down list at the top which lets you choose the one to use by default. You can also browse for a directory to place the audio files in.
The Output Name section lets you control how the audio files are layed out in your chosen directory. For instance, in the default setup, the first track of my CD might be extracted to "~/Music/iio/Rapture/01 - Rapture [Radio Edit].ogg".
The Strip special characters checkbox controls whether the file name should be made safe for the command line. That involves removing characters like /, \, *, ? and so on. It's probably a good idea to have this checked.
Output format
Here you can choose which file format you want to save your files to. The default is Ogg Vorbis, which is recommended due to its high in quality, low in size nature, as well as being an open format available to all. Ogg Vorbis can be played by virtually all Linux installations out of the box, and WinAmp for Windows also supports it.
Other formats are available however. The MP3 codec is widely known and used, and has good hardware support. If you have a portable MP3 player that doesn't accept Vorbis files, you may wish to use this so you can upload it to the device.
FLAC is a lossless codec, as opposed to Vorbis and MP3 which are lossy. Lossless codecs don't throw any information away at all, which means you get a 100% faithful reproduction of the original sound. Lossy codecs use complex mathematical constructions, called psychoacoustic models, to eliminate information that you cannot normally hear. The end result sounds virtually identical to the original, even though it is in reality substantially different.
If quality is of the highest concern to you, and you have lots of disk space to burn, you might want to try FLAC. The WAV raw audio format is the lowest common denominator format - it isn't compressed at all, and will give the biggest files. It's often useful for professional audio work, but for most uses you won't want to choose this option.
Some of the options may be unavailable here. If that's the case, you need to install support for the relevant formats into GStreamer. The exact way you do this will depend on your setup.
